subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... Why static data? You can just write something like private static final String myStaticTestData = ... ; in your test class -- no need for setUp() or the
messageBody:
On Thursday 26 May 2005 13:13, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> 1. If you need to initialize static data before each test.

Why static data? You can just write something like
private static final String myStaticTestData = "...";
in your test class -- no need for setUp() or the constructor.
What am I missing here?

> Instance data can be initialized in the constructor because JUnit
> creates a new, clean object for each test.

Yes, and the only reason for setUp vs constructor is that there is no
destructor and sometimes the setUp / tearDown pair may be more intuitive.
It's also a matter of test terminology -- a test can have its setup, its
assertions, and its teardown.
Even though it makes JUnit tests look kind of procedural... lots of
procedures...

> 2. If a test uses a lot of memory or some other scarce resource, and
> you need to explicitly free that resource in tearDown instead of
> waiting for garbage collection to do it.

The garbage collector is not even able to collect test objects unless they
are freed in tearDown(); see item 4.18 in the JUnit FAQ.

Robert
